awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Reducing the Threat from Active Shooters Using Miniature Air Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a non-lethal building defense system that will guarantee that no one can draw a firearm without being immediately detected and disabled.  In the time that it takes for first-time responders to arrive at an active shooting scene, the lives of many defenseless civilians may be taken.  This technology seeks to eliminate this time delay and to render the assailant unconscious.  The proposed technology has the potential of having high impact on society as mass killings of children and innocent civilians leave deep scars for many decades.  This technology will allow people to feel safer in any building, decreasing stress and anxiety, and may result in greater productivity.  Applications include houses of worship, stores, homes, and commercial businesses.  In addition, the proposed technology will allow those who cannot afford security guards to be safe from shooters.  For those who can afford security guards, this technology offers a higher level of defense that also will help eliminate shoot-outs.  

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a two-component, non-lethal building defense system composed of a robust, accurate target detection and classification system and a highly maneuverable Miniature Air Vehicle (MAV).  The proposed research is based on weapon detection using computer vision, artificial intelligence, and machine learning algorithms to develop a multistep and multilayer system that combines multi-sensor data streams that feed a real-time dynamic world model through an object fusion subsystem, a rule-based system for refinement, a risk assessment system to advise appropriate actions, and physics models.  These multiple steps and multiple layers will increase the likeliness of correctly identifying a weapon and a threating situation.  Research for the second component will focus on the design of a MAV that will be small enough and fast enough to be hard to defend against, while capable of removing the threat.  The MAV will be equipped with advanced target tracking with a non-lethal disabling payload.  This research will advance scientific and technological understanding of MAV and aerodynamic surfaces operating at Reynolds numbers below 50,000 and the understanding and achievement of autonomous systems with exceptionally low false positives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant was through the I-Corps program. The team started by attending the I-Coprs workshop, which was very beneficial to the entire team.  The product being developing was to build a nonlethal device that would stop active shooters before they cause any harm during mass shooting events. The device would detect the shooter using computer vision, and using tracking software shoot a miniature air-vehicles that would disable them. The vehicle may cause some harm or pain but would not kill the shooter.  We called this the GreenBird system.  We developed a business model canvas, a list of hypotheses, questions to address the hypotheses, and began interviews with potential customers.  The initial targeted scenarios were mass shootings in K-12 schools and universities, shootings at houses of worship, and robberies at corner convenience markets (7-11, QuickStop, …). One hundred and fifty-seven interviews were conducted with these potential clients.  
The results of the interviews were somewhat surprising to us. The school administrators had no interest in the system and it was not a question of security but a question of liability; They felt if they had purchased a system to stop active shooters and it did not work 100%, they would be liable.  Houses of worship did have concerns for the safety of their congregations, but most did not think they had the funds to purchase any system; those that did have resources already had other systems in place. For corner store markets, they have robberies folded into their operating budgets. They stated they would rather just give the money from the cash register, which is emptied periodically so there is never a great loss, rather than jeopardizing their employees.
At this stage of the project, we realized there was little to no interest in the GreenBird system. One of the points of emphasis at the I-Corps workshop was when the technology you are developing has little to no interest from consumers, you need to pivot. We decided to explore the agricultural market. Our initial hypothesis was that animal predators destroy crops and/or attack and kill livestock resulting in enormous economical loses. Farmers need an effective way to deter predator attacks. Using the same computer vision algorithms, various predators can be detected, then noise and motion can be used to scare them away and if needed a water gun could be used.
The potential customers were divided into two general groups: livestock farmers and crops farmers; the first was owners of large animal livestock and medium-small animal livestock and the second includes owners of crops, orchards, and vineyards. A series of hypotheses were made for each segment and questions to address each hypothesis were developed.  In total, two-hundred and seven interviews were done at the farms or at farmer’s markets. Some of the highlights of the interviews are given below.
Owners of Crops and Orchards:  
Farmers have very creative ways to scare away small animals that try to eat their produce: for instance, farmers use inflatable scare crows which seem to be effective in scaring away animals. Other farmers use liquid softener, plants that some predators don’t like such as Marigold, or a common noise from radio at night to stop animals from eating their crops.
Farmers claim they have so much land and produce so many fruits that birds eating them is not really a concern (This was a very common comment from farmers)
At this point Orchards and Crops farmers were removed from our business model canvas.
Owners of Vineyards:
Vintners use a number of techniques to scare away animals: nets, lasers, noise, electric fences, etc.  These methods work well and they see no need for newer high-tech solutions.
At this point vineyard owners were removed from our business model canvas.
Owners of large Livestock:
•    Most predator attacks on big animals do not happen often, 1-3 per 10 years.
•    Big animals (Cows, Alpacas, Llamas, Pigs) can defend themselves.
•    In commercial farms, animals are inside a closed area and predators can’t enter easily. There are well established bio-systems to ensure that mice, rats, or bigger animals don’t enter.
At this point Big animals farmers and commercial farmers were removed from our business model canvas.
Free range poultry and sheep farmers:
Farmers use a combination of solutions, one solution alone is not enough, for instance, dogs and geese, dogs and fence
Some farmers use guard animals such as dogs, geese, llamas, donkeys.
There was no need for our solution among free-range poultry or sheep farmers.


Conclusion: The farmers of all segments are satisfied with the methods they are currently using to avoid predator attacks on their crops, orchards, or livestock (all sizes). There was very little to no interest in a high-tech solution to scare away the predators.

Modified by: Robert Gamache
